displayed_text: Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know? We, we have a look now which is not a super early look but it still is within, you know, a few weeks of finishing. Sometimes when times goes on, then, you know, you’ll have new stuff, but- Family Member: So no, no, no, uh, MRIs in order right now? Doctor: No. Unless you’re telling me you’re worse. Family Member: Well, he’s got, he’s in pain, but that might be sciatic. He don’t know. Patient: No. Doctor: Man, it’s always your darn back. Family Member: Well, hip and leg. Doctor: Is it the hip and leg? Patient: Well, it’s, it like radiates from here down. Family Member: The pelvis down. Doctor: Uh, refresh my memory. Have we ever MRI’d that?

Patient: Before we leave. Doctor: So we make some decisions. Patient: Anything else? Family Member: No unless you want to ask her about… Patient: No. Doctor: What? Laughs]] Patient: Oh I got a little inflammation from the penis um well inversion you know and you’re gonna get urine up in there and it’s gonna get inflamed. I’ve been using my statin ointment and that helps somewhat, but uh… Doctor: I think you might need surgery to fix that problem. Patient: A surgeon? Doctor: Yeah a urologist. Patient: That sounds like fun. laughs]] Doctor: I know. Laughs]] Well it’s better than constantly dealing with this pestering problem. Family Member: The pestering is what it is.

Patient: February Doctor: But not since you last saw me? Patient: Oh, no. But I did take iron then, but I haven’t taken it since. So. Doctor: Have you been thinking clearly? Any issues with your – just how you process things? Patient: No. (Clicking) Doctor: Anything new on your body today? Rashes? Skin changes? Patient: No. Doctor: Swelling? Bumps, Lumps? Patient: No. No. Family Member: Are those, uh, energy drinks that you see on TV problematic? I’m asking sort of for myself, too. Doctor: Uh. I mean they have a lot of calories in them, and so, uh, it’s more about why he’s takin’ them or Family Member: Oh, okay.

Family Member: Okay, good. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: If we can get him looked at it’s… Doctor: Well how about any, how is the pain in the neck? Did that flare up? Patient: No. That’s gone. Doctor: That’s been gone too? Patient: Yeah it’s been gone. Doctor: It didn’t come back in between at all? Patient: No. That was a one-week episode. Doctor: Can you move your neck? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Side to side? Does that bring on pain?

Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. They were dealing with somebody that was off, a robber or something. Patient: Okay. Well that didn’t affect our drive. Doctor: No. But I’m sure with the game. Never, never rush. Don’t stress. You know? It’s not great for your sugar and then you’re on the XTANDI. Family Member: You were only fifteen minutes late so it’s fine. Patient: Yeah. And the other issue was this (laugh) Patient: We weren’t aware what we were doing. Family Member: Yeah you were. We had an appointment with this guy Come in at eleven thirty. Right. Doctor: It’s all your fault his sugar is low, not back and forth. (Laughs) Patient: No. He said no (Laughter) Doctor: You feeling better? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: The actual treatment, also, like I said, on the study, there’s a two out of three chance that you will get the treatment. Okay? Uh, A___? I’ll tell S___ to come in. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: But, uh, you know, I think it is a chance, and none of us have any control over what you get. But, but, at a minimum- Patient: Or- Doctor: -this is sort of the only chance we have of getting it right now. Patient: Well, will they tell you, uh, if I went down there and spent a couple of days and had the testing done-. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Will they tell you, uh, if it’s needed? Would they tell if it’s needed or not in lieu of that? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Because I can ask. They won’t show me the films, but they have a special radiologist read it, and they come back to me and tell me if you are likely to go on the study or not. Because if your cancer doesn’t have that antigen, it’s pointless to go on the medication. Patient: Right. It can’t- Doctor: So then we wouldn’t move forward with the treatment.

Patient: Oh yeah, they said for pain, and I didn’t need that. Doctor: Well that’s for spasm, but they also give you medicine for pain, Hydro-per ; so you can take either of those two medicines. Doctor: So five milligrams Patient: What’s a spasm? Family Member: Spasm. Doctor: Uh your bladder. You feel a cramping down. Patient: No, I didn’t feel that. Doctor: So that’s . And then you also are taking calcium. Family Member: No. Doctor: Just the Vitamin D. Patient: Just Vitamin D. Patient: I used to take that when I was playing actively tennis, but I haven’t been playing tennis now for a while, so

Patient: To go to Cornell. Doctor: Cornell or UCLA, so, yeah. Patient: Well, I guess I would ask you, if possible, to check out both avenues. I’d want to see which one. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I mean my interest, our interest, is just to stop this stuff from growing. It seems to be growing at a consistent pace. I don’t know if it’s slow, fast, or whatever, but it’s not stopping. And do you think that this, this sort of, from what you know from this, from the, you know PSMA, that would have a real uh opportunity to stop the growth? Doctor: Yeah. I think from the data they published, it actually looks really good, uh, and- Patient: If it’s so good, why don’t they, why does it take so long in the U.S. then to get these? Doctor: So, in Germany, and Australia, I know they’re also doing it in Australia. I know it’s a little farther for you- Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Uh in Germany they have a law that if the doctor thinks something is beneficial it doesn’t have to be you know like you know in America, FDA approved. So the FDA, the bar is show me it makes people live longer. It’s a pretty high bar. Because that requires a lot of patients, a lot time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but at the end of the day, you feel really confident that what I’m giving you could help.

Healthcare Professional: Thirty days, I do believe. From the, um, the, the Doctor: From the hormone first Healthcare Professional: hormone first. Doctor: Right, so if he gets this hormone therapy on the twenty-first, then Healthcare Professional: On the twenty-first, then he could. December. Probably, uh, we could stretch it out to the end of December. Doctor: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. We can get you started. Family Member: What are the pills? Doctor: Uh, the pills are bicalutamide. So, basically, they, uh, block, uh, your cancer cell from using testosterone that’s in your body. So, right away, they start treating your cancer. Uh. But, when I give you your shot, uh, the testosterone shoots up. It could make your cancer worse in that few days. And, so, I wanna protect that surge of testosterone that occurs when we give you the first shot. Patient: Hmmm. Family Member: The first shot of the hormone? Doctor: The first shot of the hormones.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: if we can just contain it. Now, sometimes people just take it twice a day, kind of like before bed for sure so you sleep well Patient: Right. Doctor: and then when you’re kind of up and running whether it’s after breakfast and you’re like I’m gonna get as much stuff as I can done and I’m just gonna relax and wait for my next dose. Some of my guys have to take it three times a day and some of my guys are just like I’m okay, I can stand this stuff, it’s doable but at night I just can’t sleep. It’s just there all the time the achiness and pain. Patient: Right. Doctor: and they take it at night. However you do it just know it will constipate you. Patient: I know that, yes. Doctor: And you know that’s just a miserable status Patient: Yes. Yes. Doctor: to be in so we have to have you take over-the-counter um stool softeners, MiraLAX, so kind of almost like oh, I took two of these I maybe have to see where my poop situation is, Patient: Right. Doctor: I might need to take MiraLAX twice or I might have to add MiraLAX to Senokot or you go down the poop aisle at Rite Aid or CVS Patient: Right.

Patient: What would you recommend? Doctor: Okay so my recommendation is mainly based on trying our best not to take away options from you, okay. And the way I see it if we go to Lynparza right now, this Xtandi plus BET1 inhibitor goes away as an option because you have to be on the Xtandi currently before when they can consider you for the study. So I’m leaning towards if you qualify for the study, if everything goes right then you should go with the Xtandi plus BET inhibitor the study based option first and if that doesn’t work or if it doesn’t if you’re not eligible for whatever reason, then we go to the Lynparza. I mean that is available to us as a fall back at any point. Family Member: Okay. Patient: So you’d say try the uh uh BET thing and uh if that doesn’t work go to the Lynparza which is the PARP inhibitor and continue with the Xtandi? Family Member: With, with the BET. Doctor: The Lynparza we’ll see, most likely I will stop the Xtandi at that point. Patient: Okay do you think… Doctor: Because we’ll really have exhausted that Xtandi is not working definitely before we decide to switch to Lynparza at that point. Patient: How soon will you know? I mean the… Family Member: With the BET. Doctor: With the BET? Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: Will he need to have somebody come with him? Doctor: Uh, no, but how is he going to – do you have transportation arrangements made? Family Member: He drives. Doctor: Oh, okay. Family Member: He drives. Shit. J__ drives everywhere. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Is for the biopsy that we will need to do – Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: - for the study and on the day that he’s just starting something new- Family Member: Yeah. Right. Doctor: I would- Family Member: You want somebody here. Doctor: At least tell you that you need to be available if we need to call you.
